Ag.fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin argentum)
Ag.name: Silver

Al.fact: alumina, from Latin alumen (gen. aluminis), 'bitter salt, alum'
Al.name: Aluminium

Am.fact: The Americas, as the element was first synthesised on the continent, by analogy with europium
Am.name: Americium

As.fact: French arsenic, from Greek arsenikon 'yellow arsenic' (influenced by arsenikos, 'masculine' or 'virile'), from a West Asian wanderword ultimately from Old Iranian *zarniya-ka, 'golden'
As.name: Arsenic

Au.fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin aurum)
Au.name: Gold

Be.fact: beryl, a mineral (ultimately from the name of Belur in southern India)
Be.name: Beryllium

Bi.fact: German Wismut, from weiss Masse 'white mass', unless from Arabic
Bi.name: Bismuth

Bk.fact: Berkeley, California, where the element was first synthesised, by analogy with terbium
Bk.name: Berkelium

Cd.fact: New Latin cadmia, from King Kadmos
Cd.name: Cadmium

Ce.fact: the dwarf planet Ceres, considered a planet at the time
Ce.name: Cerium

Cf.fact: California, where the element was first synthesised
Cf.name: Californium

Cm.fact: Pierre Curie and Marie Curie, French physicists and chemists
Cm.name: Curium

Cu.fact: English word, from Latin cuprum, from Ancient Greek Kypros 'Cyprus'
Cu.name: Copper

D.fact: One of two stable isotopes of Hydrogen, the other being Protium. The Deuterium nucleus contains one proton and one neutron, whereas Protium only has one proton. Thus, Deuterium has twice the mass of Protium.  Sometimes referred to as 2H.
D.name: Deuterium

Db.fact: Dubna, Russia, where the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research is located
Db.name: Dubnium

Ds.fact: Darmstadt, Germany, where the element was first synthesised
Ds.name: Darmstadtium

Fe.fact: English word (the symbol Fe is derived from Latin ferrum)
Fe.name: Iron

Fl.fact: Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions, part of JINR, where the element was synthesised; itself named after Georgy Flyorov, Russian physicist
Fl.name: Flerovium

Gd.fact: gadolinite, a mineral named after Johan Gadolin, Finnish chemist, physicist and mineralogist
Gd.name: Gadolinium

Hg.fact: Mercury, Roman God of commerce, communication, and luck, known for his speed and mobility (The symbol is from the element's Latin name hydrargyrum, derived from Greek hydrargyros, ater-silver')
Hg.name: Mercury

Hs.fact: New Latin Hassia, 'Hesse' (a state in Germany)
Hs.name: Hassium

In.fact: Latin indicum, 'indigo' (colour found in its spectrum)
In.name: Indium

Ir.fact: Iris, the Greek Goddess of the rainbow
Ir.name: Iridium

K.fact: New Latin potassa, 'potash' (the symbol K is derived from Latin kalium)
K.name: Potassium

Lv.fact: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, California, which collaborated with JINR on its synthesis
Lv.name: Livermorium

Mc.fact: Moscow Oblast, Russia, where the element was first synthesised
Mc.name: Moscovium

Md.fact: Dmitri Mendeleev, Russian chemist and inventor who proposed the periodic table
Md.name: Mendelevium

Mg.fact: Magnesia, a district of Eastern Thessaly in Greece
Mg.name: Magnesium

Mn.fact: corrupted from magnesia negra; see Magnesium
Mn.name: Manganese

Mo.fact: Greek molybdaina, 'piece of lead', from molybdos, 'lead'
Mo.name: Molybdenum

Na.fact: English soda (the symbol Na is derived from New Latin natrium, coined from German Natron, 'natron')
Na.name: Sodium

Nb.fact: Niobe, daughter of king Tantalus from Greek mythology
Nb.name: Niobium

Nh.fact: Japanese Nihon, 'Japan' (where the element was first synthesised)
Nh.name: Nihonium

Ni.fact: Nickel, a mischievous sprite of German miner mythology
Ni.name: Nickel

No.fact: Alfred Nobel, Swedish chemist and engineer
No.name: Nobelium

Np.fact: Neptune, the eighth planet in the Solar System
Np.name: Neptunium

Pa.fact: proto- (from Greek protos, 'first, before') + actinium, which is produced through the radioactive decay of protactinium
Pa.name: Protactinium

Pb.fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin plumbum)
Pb.name: Lead

Pd.fact: the asteroid Pallas, considered a planet at the time
Pd.name: Palladium

Po.fact: Latin Polonia, 'Poland' (the home country of Marie Curie)
Po.name: Polonium

Pu.fact: the dwarf planet Pluto, considered the ninth planet in the Solar System at the time
Pu.name: Plutonium

Rf.fact: Ernest Rutherford, chemist and physicist from New Zealand
Rf.name: Rutherfordium

Sb.fact: Latin antimonium, the origin of which is uncertain: folk etymologies suggest it is derived from Greek anti ('against') + monos ('alone'), or Old French anti-moine, 'Monk's bane', but it could be from or related to Arabic _itmid, 'antimony', reformatted as a Latin word. (The symbol derives from Latin stibium 'stibnite'.)
Sb.name: Antimony

Sm.fact: samarskite, a mineral named after Colonel Vasili Samarsky-Bykhovets, Russian mine official
Sm.name: Samarium

Sn.fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin stannum)
Sn.name: Tin

Ta.fact: King Tantalus, father of Niobe from Greek mythology
Ta.name: Tantalum

Th.fact: Thor, the Scandinavian God of thunder
Th.name: Thorium

Ti.fact: Titans, the sons of the Earth Goddess of Greek mythology
Ti.name: Titanium

Tm.fact: Thule, the ancient name for an unclear northern location
Tm.name: Thulium

U.fact: Uranus, the seventh planet in the Solar System
U.name: Uranium

V.fact: Vanadis, an Old Norse name for the Scandinavian Goddess Freyja
V.name: Vanadium

W.fact: Swedish tung sten, 'heavy stone' (The symbol is from wolfram, the old name of the tungsten mineral wolframite)
W.name: Tungsten

Xe.fact: Greek xenon, neuter form of xenos 'strange'
Xe.name: Xenon

Zn.fact: Most likely from German Zinke, 'prong' or 'tooth', though some suggest Persian sang, 'stone'
Zn.name: Zinc
